It’s been a little stressful 😉 I vividly remember on my last graduation day - undergrad - getting a call from a news director for a traffic reporter job in Houston. I was thrilled. I was barely 20 & thought this was a huge setback (ha!). I immediately started making more resume tapes and mailing them off at the post office daily.  I’ve been fortunate to have had an incredible TV career so far - from reporting from Oklahoma’s death row to breaking stories about political corruption.  I’ve also made lifelong friends in many of my colleagues. Still, three years ago I wasn’t where I wanted to be. I needed a challenge. Something to help me refocus and pull me out of my comfort zone.  So here I am. I’m excited to add another dimension to my career with a law degree. (By the way, law school is no joke - I quickly learned to study when and wherever I could.) I’m looking forward to seeing where this next chapter takes me and the people I can impact along the way. Some of the greatest influencers I know are lawyers. I woke up this morning thinking about that first TV job I didn’t get when I was 20 (oh, the heartbreak! 😆) and the ride it’s been all the years since then. Here’s what I’ve learned: Think big. Don’t limit yourself. Success comes to those who choose to live the life they want.  Cheers to the class of 2019. 🥂

Since I announced I’m running for the U.S. Senate against Jim Inhofe, I’ve been asked several times on social media what qualifies me for the job. I could answer with: I’m a practicing attorney & I started a successful TV career in a cut-throat corporate man’s world when I was 20, but the most straightforward answer I have is this. I’m like my friends who want affordable, quality healthcare. I want my neighbors to retire with dignity, and I want our Oklahoma kids - our future - to have the best quality education possible. Bottom line: I’m tired of DC partisan politics. I’m tired of a Senator who refuses to act. I’m tired of a Senator who has done nothing to put us on a better path forward since I was learning how to write. I’m an Oklahoman. I’m all in.
